item.title: Pi Hole - simple ad blocker for your network
item.description: Advertisements in web pages can be a nuisance. But they are a necessary evil because companies/bloggers producing high quality content have to earn a living. Troy Hunt recently wrote a nice post on the subject.

item.title: Remotly measuring temperatures with a Raspberry Pi using radio frequency modules from Ciseco (Part 3: UI)
item.description: Part 1 describes how to setup the hardware, part 2 describes how to to record/persist the sensor information. In this post I'll describe how to display the data. TL;DR Download and unzip the source code from https://github.

item.title: Remotly measuring temperatures with a Raspberry Pi using radio frequency modules from Ciseco (Part 2: Software)
item.description: In the previous post I described how to setup the hardware for measuring temperatures at home. This post will use a small python program to save the recorded temperatures to a database.

item.title: Installing Seafile on Raspberry Pi
item.description: With all the security issues in the past relating to privacy I've been wanting to install a private cloud service similar to Dropbox for some time now. So, here's a post on how to install Seafile on the Raspberry Pi.

item.title: Setting up a network printer using Raspberry Pi
item.description: This post by Lynsay describes in detail how to convert a non-network printer into a network printer. You will have to install CUPS and SAMBA on your Raspberry Pi. Once your done you can access the printer from any OS (windows, linux, mac) within your network.

item.title: RPi/XBMC: Keeping content in sync
item.description: If you have multiple Rasperry Pi/XBMC clients and want to keep your “history” in sync (watch a movie in room1, stop, start the same movie in room2 and resume) do not want to individually update every RPi/XBMC client if the content of your data storage changes then this post might be for you.

item.title: Mapping missing context menu in OpenELEC with Remote Control HAMA MCE
item.description: The IR remote control HAMA MCE works out of the box with XBMC. Except that XBMC's context menu is not mapped to any key. An alternative solution to the one provided here is using your smart phone or tablet as a remote control with the excellent Yatse app.
